column1: San José (Spanish: [saŋ xoˈse]; literally meaning "Saint Joseph") is the capital and largest city of Costa Rica
column2: and the capital of the province of the same name. It is in the centre of the country
column3: in the mid-west of the Central Valley
column4: within San José Canton. San José is Costa Rica's seat of national government
column5: focal point of political and economic activity
column6: and major transportation hub. San José Canton's population was 288
column8: and San José's municipal land area is 44.2 square kilometers (17.2 square miles)
column10: 980 residents in 2015. Together with several other cantons of the central valley
column13: it forms the country's Greater Metropolitan Area
column14: with an estimated population of over 2 million in 2017. The city is named in honor of Joseph of Nazareth.

column1: Founded in 1736 by order of Cabildo de León
column2: the population of San José rose during the 18th century through the use of colonial planning. It has historically been a city of strategic importance
column3: having been the capital of Costa Rica three times. More than a million people pass through it daily. It is home to the Museo Nacional de Costa Rica
column4: the National Theatre of Costa Rica
column5: and La Sabana Metropolitan Park. Juan Santamaría International Airport serves the city.

column1: San José is notable among Latin American cities for its high quality of life
column2: security
column3: level of globalization
column6: and recognized institutions. According to studies on Latin America
column7: San José is one of the safest and least violent cities in the region. In 2006
column8: the city was appointed Ibero-American Capital of Culture. According to The MasterCard Global Destinations Cities Index 2012
column9: San José is the sixth-most visited destination in Latin America
column10: ranking first in Central America. San José ranked 15th in the world's fastest-growing destination cities by visitor cross-border spending. It is considered a "Beta-" global city by GaWC.

column1: The population of San José grew during the eighteenth-century colonization planning
column2: which was different from the traditional foundation plans of Spanish cities in the continent of Central America.

column1: Founded in 1736 by order of Cabildo de León
column2: its objective was to concentrate the scattered inhabitants of the Aserrí Valley. De León thus ordered the construction of a chapel near the area known as La Boca del Monte which was completed a year later. That year St. Joseph was chosen as parish patron
column3: hence its name. The chapel
column5: was erected with help from the church of Cartago.

column2: San José was not founded by formal decree and thus lacked a city government. It was not until the enactment of the Constitution of Cádiz in 1812 when San José had its first city government. On 18 October 1813
column3: the area was first defined as a city by presbyter Florencio del Castillo
column4: on behalf of the Spanish government
column5: title which was then lost in 1814 when Ferdinand VII of Spain annulled the proceedings of the courts. The municipal government was restored in 1820 along with the title of city and in 1823 San José became the capital of Costa Rica. This makes San José is one of the youngest capital cities in Latin America by year of conception.

column1: Population and economic growth were spurred by improvements in access to water and the installment of the Tobacco Factory in 1782. The accumulation of capital brought by tobacco plantations allowed the city to economically surpass neighboring provinces.The first modern urban neighborhood carries the name of his founder
column2: the French coffee entrepreneur Monsieur Amon
column3: and was created in the late 19th century
column4: in line with Belle Époque contemporary architecture. Barrio Amon
column5: as well as the National Theatre
column6: remain symbols of the so-called Costa Rican coffee golden age.

column1: Today San José is a modern city with bustling commerce and brisk expressions of art and architecture. Spurred by the country's improved tourism industry
column2: it is a significant destination and stopover for foreign visitors.San José exerts a strong influence because of its proximity to other cities (Alajuela
column3: Heredia and Cartago) and the country's demographic assemblage in the Central Valley.

column1: The borders of San José city
column2: as defined in the Administrative Territorial Division and stipulated in the Executive Decree 11562 of 27 May 1980
column3: assign the borders of San José canton except an East sector of Uruca district.  Therefore the city is composed of the totality of the districts of Merced

column1: San José has a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen climate classification Aw). Precipitation varies widely between the driest month (6.3 mm (0.25 in)) and the wettest month (355.1 mm (13.98 in))
column2: while average temperatures vary little. The hottest month is April with an average temperature of 23.7 °C (74.7 °F)
column3: while the coolest month is October with an average temperature of 21.8 °C (71.2 °F).

column1: Costa Rica has developed high education levels. As of 2011 97.6% of the population over 10 was literate
column2: 96% of children aged 6–11 attend primary school and 71% of students of high-school age attend high-school. The country as a whole has the highest education levels in Central America and one of the best in Latin America. This is especially true for San José
column3: the nation's educational hub home to a large number of public and private universities.University of Santo Tomas
column4: the first university of Costa Rica was established here in 1843. That institution maintained close ties with the Roman Catholic Church and was closed in 1888 by the progressive and anti-clerical government of President Bernardo Soto Alfaro as part of a campaign to modernize public education. The schools of law
column7: and pharmacy continued to operate independently
column8: but Costa Rica had no university proper until 1940
column9: when those four schools were re-united to establish the modern  University of Costa Rica (UCR)
column10: during the reformist administration of President Rafael Ángel Calderón Guardia.

column1: The city's public education system is composed of pre-schools
column2: elementary and high schools (from grades 7 to 11)
column3: which are located in all of the city's districts and are under the supervision of the Ministry of Public Education. Nevertheless
column4: private institutions do exist within the city. These educational institutions range from pre-schools to universities. Most tend to be bilingual
column5: teaching subjects in either French or English and Spanish
column7: apart from just teaching a certain language.

column1: San José is one of Latin America's safer cities. As of 19 June 2012
column2: both city and nation reduced their crime indices considerably. Nationwide
column3: crime was reduced from 12.5 to 9.5 incidents per 100

column2: new police equipment was issued by the government
column3: and the security budget was increased. President Laura Chinchilla's government has donated vehicles and other equipment to the police department on at least two occasions.The city's greater metropolitan area (in Los Yoses
column4: San Pedro) also serves as the headquarters of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights.

column1: San José has a number of theaters
column2: many with European-inspired architecture. These buildings serve as the city's main tourist attractions
column3: not only because of their architecture
column7: which include traditional and modern Costa Rican and San Josefinan culture.The most well-known are:

The Melico Salazar Theater (Teatro Popular Melico Salazar).

The National Auditorium of The Children's Museum of Costa Rica (Museo de los Niños).The National Theater of Costa Rica  (considered the finest historic building in the capital and known for its exquisite interior which includes its lavish Italian furnishings) and the Melico Salazar Theater present drama
column2: dance performances and concerts throughout the year. Nevertheless
column3: other 'smaller' theaters can be found throughout the city and provide a large array of entertainment.

column1: El Teatro Variedades (1892) is San José's oldest theatre.
San José is also host to various museums. These museums allow visitors to view Costa Rican history
column2: scientific discoveries
column3: pre-Columbian era culture and art
column4: as well as modern Costa Rican art. The city is also host to the nation's museum of gold and museum of jade.

==== Plazas ====
Plazas, or town squares, are very prominent across San José's districts.

Culture Square — La Plaza de La Cultura (one example)


== Transportation ==
San José has several internal transportation networks that connect the city districts and metropolitan area; as well as national transportation networks that connect the city to other parts of Costa Rica.
San José is undergoing modernization in transportation. The mayor, Johnny Araya, has announced the establishment of an urban tramway system that will, in its first phase, cover the central core of the city going from west to east. This entire plan was announced and publicly presented in February 2011 by the city mayor and Costa Rican President, Laura Chinchilla.
On 27 September 2012, San José disclosed plans to install its first street signs, about 22,000 signs and plaques. It is estimated that the lack of proper street names for directions causes the loss of $720 million a year by the Inter-American Development Bank in 2008, due to undelivered, returned or re-sent mail.


=== Buses ===
Private bus companies connect different areas of the city with each other and the suburbs. Services to other parts of the country are provided by other private companies which have stations or stops spread all over the city centre. There are also bus services between Juan Santamaría International Airport and downtown San José.


=== Train ===
The Instituto Costarricense de Ferrocarriles, or the state owned railway institute, is in charge of all of Costa Rica's railways. In 2004, this institution began work on the establishment of an inter-urban railway network. This network would connect Tibás, Heredia, San Antonio de Belén, Pavas, San Pedro de Montes de Oca, Sabanilla, and Curridabat, among other locations.
There are plans to expand this inter-urban railway system into Cartago, Alajuela, and the Juan Santamaría International Airport.
Trains run to Heredia from Estación Atlantico and San Antonio de Belen and from Estación Pacifico.


=== Taxis ===
San José public taxi services complement the urban transportation network. Taxis are characterized by their red color and belong to registered cooperatives. There are other taxi services which do not belong to the registered system, there are also taxis from the airport that are usually orange.
The car-sharing company Uber has entered Costa Rica, but the government has stated that is allowed to operate.  Despite repeated clashes with and strikes from taxi drivers due to unfair competition claims, the company has continued to operate in the country.


=== Airports ===
The city is serviced by Juan Santamaría International Airport (IATA: SJO, ICAO: MROC), 23 km (14 mi) west of downtown, in the city of Alajuela, which is one of the busiest airports in Central America. In 2010, Juan Santamaría International Airport received 4.3 million passengers, most of them from international flights. In 2011, the airport was named the 3rd Best Airport in Latin America/Caribbean from the Airport Service Quality Awards by Airports Council International.The airport is undergoing a modernization plan, which is expected to be brief. The previous remodeling done to the airport cost around $7 million.
Another important airport in San José is Tobías Bolaños International Airport (IATA: SYQ, ICAO: MRPV). It is located 8 km (5 mi) north-west of the city proper and 11 km (7 mi) south-east of Juan Santamaría International Airport.


== Cuisine ==

Costa Rican cuisine (comida típica) is generally not spicy. Throughout San José, the most popular food is the national dish of gallo pinto, which is a mixture of fried rice and black beans. Gallo pinto is usually served for breakfast with tortillas and natilla, a thin sour cream. Costa Rican restaurants serving traditional food at an affordable price are called sodas and usually offer casados for lunch and dinner. A casado (which means married" in Spanish) consists of rice
column3: beans
column5: and normally comes with cabbage-and-tomato salad
column7: and/or tortillas. San José Central Market
